One has to question whether a transferred consciousness is really you at all. Also, whether the world which the transferred mind views is really viewed from your own intrinsic perspective. Is it really just a matter of closing your eyes, being transferred, then opening your eyes again & thinking... 'oh, here I am.' ? Is the person saying 'here I am' really you, or just someone with your life long memories who thinks they are? Of course, at this point it is also critical to discern between copying or moving consciousness. From the view of copying, let's try a thought experiment. You are inside room A lying on a medical couch. We will also label you consciousness A. Meanwhile inside room B is a clone of you also on a medical couch & waiting to host your transferred consciousness. After the transfer is complete... you have room A with your original consciousness & room B with consciousness B now housed in your clone. At this point both A & B are free to act independently of each other. So consciousness B is free to do anything & from your perspective inside room A you are unaware of whatever B does. So clearly consciousness A & B have separate perspectives. If this is true then how can they be the same person? The copied consciousness model doesn't really hold much merit when it comes to maintaining the integrity of the original self. The statement 'I am me'... with both A & B proclaiming it, has collapsed into absurdity.
Now, let's repeat the experiment. But this time with a variation. This time after the transfer is complete, consciousness A, (that's you by the way), is terminated. The result is consciousness B in room B and no one in room A. In this scenario can you safely assume that B is actually you & that your longevity is intact? Or are you actually dead & merely replaced by an imposter? I think it's safe to assume that the continuity in consciousness is actually broken & B is not you. When you close your eyes in room A prior to the transfer, you never actually open them again. Only your cloned consciousness inside room B does this. Remember, in the previous experiment A & B were shown to have two distinctive perspectives, each with the ability to act independently of one another. So they weren't the same person. So it follows that in this new experiment, B is not you & once consciousness A is extinguished so are you.
So much for the idea of backing up your mind on a drive to achieve immortality.

This is just a thought, but let's just say that (although this is impossible) I were to make a perfect copy of myself, my brain included, copying every detail exactly down to the spin and charge of every particle in my body.

This individual would essentially be me.

The purpose of "shedding" in the movie self/less is probably to allow continuation of consciousness, meaning well... you know how you see out of your eyes, how you hear from your ears, how you think your thoughts, instead of someone else's? How your perspective is centered around YOU? Well, the point is to now have this continuation of perspective carry on in your new body, or perhaps in a computer or something if you talk about how in science fiction you often see people uploaded to computers.

Well, while I certainly can't prove what would happen, I can definitely propose this;

If it is possible to have continuation of perspective, then I would have two perspectives simultaneously and be fully aware of it if I were to create the perfect clone I mentioned earlier, and kept both the clone and the original alive.

Of course, there's no logical way for this to happen, as we both have individual brains controlling individual bodies. Each one would have their own stream of perspective, and be more or less independent from one another. My thoughts would not be known by my clone, and my clone's thoughts would not be known to me.

Now, if I were to destroy the original me, and leave the clone alive, my stream of perspective would end. Essentially, the death I tried so hard to avoid would happen, and I would be gone. Game over.

Other people around my surviving clone, however, would more than likely confuse my clone for me, and they wouldn't be wrong; in every possible aspect, this clone would be me. Except for one; I would not experience anything my clone does, because I am dead, even if said clone would likely do almost everything I would have done exactly how I would have done it, I still would not experience it; I'd be experiencing absolutely nothing because I'm dead.

Why is it that I have a different stream of perspective than my clone? Or am I completely incorrect with my assumptions? Who knows...

This was an awesome video, but it doesn't really address the question - this is whether or not we can transfer memories.
Your consciousness is far more than just your memories. Thought experiments would suggest that your consciousness is more, even, than the entirety of your brain and body.

Imagine we advanced to the point of being able to achieve quantum teleportation - being able to recreate an exact copy of you, down to the quantum level, in a different location - but didn't need to destroy the original. Which body would you perceive out of? Both? Surely not.

Whatever came out the other end of the teleporter would LOOK identical to you (right down to the spin of the particles in your body) and would have all of your memories (and so it would THINK it was you)... but it wouldn't have your consciousness.

I do not believe that consciousness is 3-dimensionally based, and so cannot be transferred in the way this video suggests.

You didn't answer the question, you said nothing about consciousness, only memories. I'll illustrate the difference: imagine that you go unconscious, and while you are unconscious, your body disappears and reappears in two different places. Each body has the exact same neuronetwork as you had before you phased out. Now you wake up. Which body do you wake up in? It's impossible to tell by experimentation, because to the outside observer, both bodies woke up with the same memory, but for you and only you, you'd know the difference. Now maybe it is entirely possible to switch consciousness without switching memories, but you'd never know, as you're memories were all replaced.

Objection, your honor. Let's pretend that you can copy yourself (which will never happen for a lot of reasons, but for now let's just have it as given). So you copy your personality into another body, and then... you are still in your old body. And there's another person who thinks that they are you, but they really aren't, 'cause you are still here. That's it, you don't transport consciousness.

Nobody even knows where it is and why your consciousness "chose" your body. More than that, you can never know if there are other consciousnesses like yours, or are you in some sort of higher simulation, or is your consciousness single and other bodies are just soulless shells, or is there one great Consciousness that goes through every object that there is but when it's in an object (like your body) it thinks that they are you, etc. It's a mistery no one can solve, and you definetely can't "transport" it.

Hey. I'm a Bionics student and we talk about this a lot but the question here is not "could we" but "should we" . Kinda the same deal with AI. It's kinda weird scientist in movies are sometimes depicted as maniacs who would do anything for the success of their research and money. Just to calm down anyone who might get scared from the idea of making immortality possible, we usually think more about the consequences nowadays than the research itself. As an example: we have the genom of the wooly mammoth and we could clone it, no problem. An animal that died out centuries ago... The question right now is: should we clone a wooly mammoth?
And for those who are not creeped out: we could also genetically engineer and grow/print any kind of body you can imagine. Or we could wash out the cells from a dead tissue until only the structure is left and replace it with your lab grown cells effectively making you take someone's dead body. Or simulate your consciousness on a computer, robot body optional.

comment_text: Nice overview.  One key point worth mentioning is that we still do not have a definition for consciousness (see "the Hard Problem of Consciousness"), and thus we do not even have a metric for success regarding the transfer of it.  What very well might happen during such an attempt is that a copy of the current you is made, who thinks and acts as if they are you, but you are actually dead (see, "The Prestige" for an interesting take on this).

Even if we could make a perfect copy, it wouldn't be a "transferal of consciousness." There has to be some kind of continuity between the two, or else it's pretty much just dying and having some new body start to think it's you. It may do exactly what you would have done in any given circumstance and remember everything you would remember, but you wouldn't actually be experiencing any of it. The "New You" would be. I'm not sure it's possible to achieve, but if it is, it surely must involve integrating some kind of digital brain into your physical brain - like a third (or third and fourth) hemisphere - and then letting the two of them mingle until your physical body dies.

The thing that keeps getting missed in these discussions about "down/uploading yourself", is that there is no plausible reason why transmitting the "data" of a mind would in any way transmit self-consciousness.

For example, you get into a "mind transfer machine", sending yourself to Ryan Reynolds.  But, in every one of these discussions (e.g. hank on a recent Sci-show), all that gets spoken about is transferring a pattern or an image.  So, you get "copied" to Ryan Reynolds, sure, but do you actually go there.  Is the you that is reading this right now transferrable?

How horrifying would it be if everyone believed they were getting a new lease on life, and getting themselves "moved into a clone body" that was younger, when in reality, you laid down on a table and were killed.  But to everyone else, "you" are now alive in the newer body.  How horrible would this be if it started happening younger than the last few months of your life.  What if you were just 40, and were led to believe it worked, and you ended your own life, but to everyone else, you just did some commonplace "improvement", that people take to be as mundane as cosmetic surgery?

Not to mention, this obsession with transferring the brain seems to jump the shark.  I am not just my brain.  How can we be so certain that our "selfness" does not also encompass, in some oblique way, all the nerves in our bodies, the brain simply being a nexus of "self".  

I'm not convinced of any of this.  I think the map is being mistaken for the territory.

"The second it started integrating new thoughts, memories, and experiences, it would become someone else".

That is no different from how we function right now. The me in 1 second isn't the same as me 1 second before that time, because it has 1 extra second of integrated information added to it. It's still "you", but a different you, because the formation of the universe is constantly shifting forms. Nothing ever changes.

If you define "you" as a freeze frame of a single moment, then there are actually an infinite amount of different yous, none of them exactly the same. I personally define me as the COMBINATION of all of the moments of my life, past, present and future. 

If I exactly copied my consciousness into a different body right now, it would still be me, because all of the previous moments of my life added up until that point are exactly the same as they would have been otherwise.

Altering of the vessel of you consciousness isn't exactly a separation of you. While, maybe the future would be different if you hadn't moved your consciousness to a different body, the same thing can be applied to literally EVERYTHING that you do. If I decided to not type all of this here right now, then the future me would be a different me than the one who decided to type it. 

It all depends on what you define as you, and in the case of defining "you" as just a single freeze frame moment isn't exactly defining who you really are, or the possible scenarios that might actually unfold into the future "you"
